comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: NYT of February 10, 1916 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F5061FFB3E5E13738... suggests that Quigg's activities in relation to the Interborough Rapid Transit Company were under investigtion by the Thompson Committee. See comments with

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Quigg testified on February 25, 1916 (proceedings commenced, p. 871), at the Joint Legislative Committee Investigation of Public Service Commissions (Thompson Committee), at the New York County Lawyers Association Boardroom at 165 Broadway, New York. His testimony (and this picture) reflect that he was angry to be called and impatient to be finished. When Senator Thompson suggested that the photographers should take pictures, there was the following exchange, which reminds one how much smoke was generated by the photographic flash units of the day: (Photographs taken) Chairman Thompson: We will suspend now and if Mr Quigg will consent we will have pictures taken. Mr Quigg: I wish you would finish that, Mr Chairman, if it has got to be done. Mr Moss: Mr Chairman unless you have some- Chairman Thompson: It makes a lot of smoke in here and I would like to have it done with. Mr Moss: Mr Chairman, any question ? Chairman Thompson: One more photograph I am told and then we will get this smoke out of here. (Recess while windows are opened) books.google.com/books?id=ZKc3AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA928&d...

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Another photo of him is in The sun., January 05, 1916, Page 18, according to the article he was the paid attorney of the Interborough Rapid Transit company ("Wants Quigg's Hands Off").
